problem_prompt:
Your job is to consider a number theory problem, and leave a plan for the next person to solve it. The problem will be revealed one sentence at a time. You do not have the entire problem yet, thus just do whatever calcluations/planning you think will be useful for the next person. If you don't think you can make any progress, say so. The following is a portion of the entire problem, and the work/progress/message the previous person left for you. There may be errors in the provided work that was previously done and left for you, so check and fix them if necessary.
The $24^\text{th}$ day of a particular month is a Saturday.
solution: If the $24$th is a Saturday, the $17$th was also a Saturday, as were the $10$th and the $3$rd.  So the $2$nd was a Friday and the $1$st was a $\boxed{\text{Thursday}}$.
gpt_response:
Given that the $24^\text{th}$ day of the month is a Saturday, we can work backwards to find out what day of the week the $1^\text{st}$ day of the month falls on. Since there are 7 days in a week, we can subtract multiples of 7 from 24 to determine the day of the week for the $1^\text{st}$ day of the month. 

$24 \mod 7 = 3$, so the $1^\text{st}$ day of the month is $3$ days before Saturday, which is Wednesday. 

Now that we know the $1^\text{st}$ day of the month falls on a Wednesday, we can continue to figure out the days of the week for the other days in the month. This will help us determine the day of the week for the $N^\text{th}$ day of the month. We can use modular arithmetic to simplify the calculations.
